critters.name: White-tailed Deer

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees use a waggle dance to describe direction and distance to food sources.
critters.activeFact: A hive maintains temperature by fanning wings and clustering, acting like a living thermostat.
factHistory: Honeybees use a waggle dance to describe direction and distance to food sources.
A hive maintains temperature by fanning wings and clustering, acting like a living thermostat.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can warm their flight muscles by vibrating, letting them fly in cooler weather.
critters.activeFact: They excel at buzz pollination, shaking pollen loose from certain flowers with vibration.
factHistory: Bumblebees can warm their flight muscles by vibrating, letting them fly in cooler weather.
They excel at buzz pollination, shaking pollen loose from certain flowers with vibration.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers ‚Äòsing‚Äô by rubbing body parts together, creating species-specific sounds.
critters.activeFact: Their powerful hind legs can launch them quickly to escape predators.
factHistory: Grasshoppers ‚Äòsing‚Äô by rubbing body parts together, creating species-specific sounds.
Their powerful hind legs can launch them quickly to escape predators.

critters.name: Gray Wolf
critters.summary: Social predator that travels in family groups.
critters.fact: Wolves coordinate hunts with body language and vocalizations, not just chasing speed.
critters.activeFact: A pack‚Äôs territory can be large, and travel routes are often repeated like mapped patrol lines.
factHistory: Wolves coordinate hunts with body language and vocalizations, not just chasing speed.
A pack‚Äôs territory can be large, and travel routes are often repeated like mapped patrol lines.

critters.name: Red Wolf
critters.summary: Rare canid with a lean build and reddish coat tones.
critters.fact: Red wolves communicate with scent marking and howls to maintain spacing and pair bonds.
critters.activeFact: They hunt mostly small to medium prey and rely heavily on stealth and timing.
factHistory: Red wolves communicate with scent marking and howls to maintain spacing and pair bonds.
They hunt mostly small to medium prey and rely heavily on stealth and timing.

critters.name: Moose
critters.summary: Large browser that favors wetlands and young forest growth.
critters.fact: Moose have long legs that help them move through deep snow and swampy ground.
critters.activeFact: They can dive for aquatic plants, using water to cool off and avoid insects in summer.
factHistory: Moose have long legs that help them move through deep snow and swampy ground.
They can dive for aquatic plants, using water to cool off and avoid insects in summer.

critters.name: Elk
critters.summary: Herd-forming deer species found in select Michigan regions.
critters.fact: Elk use vocal calls to keep herd contact and communicate during the breeding season.
critters.activeFact: They often feed in open areas near forest edges, especially at dawn and dusk.
factHistory: Elk use vocal calls to keep herd contact and communicate during the breeding season.
They often feed in open areas near forest edges, especially at dawn and dusk.

critters.name: Groundhog
critters.summary: Burrowing herbivore common along fields and edges.
critters.fact: Groundhogs dig extensive burrow systems with multiple entrances for quick escapes.
critters.activeFact: They often create ‚Äòlookout‚Äô mounds near burrow openings to scan for danger.
factHistory: Groundhogs dig extensive burrow systems with multiple entrances for quick escapes.
They often create ‚Äòlookout‚Äô mounds near burrow openings to scan for danger.

critters.name: Eastern Chipmunk
critters.summary: Striped ground squirrel seen near logs, rocks, and feeders.
critters.fact: Eastern chipmunks keep burrows tidy, often separating nesting areas from food storage chambers.
critters.activeFact: They can carry multiple seeds at once thanks to expandable cheek pouches.
factHistory: Eastern chipmunks keep burrows tidy, often separating nesting areas from food storage chambers.
They can carry multiple seeds at once thanks to expandable cheek pouches.

critters.name: Weasel
critters.summary: Small, fast predator that hunts rodents in tight spaces.
critters.fact: Weasels can follow prey into burrows because their bodies are long and flexible.
critters.activeFact: Their quick, zigzag movement helps confuse prey and avoid larger predators.
factHistory: Weasels can follow prey into burrows because their bodies are long and flexible.
Their quick, zigzag movement helps confuse prey and avoid larger predators.

critters.name: Ermine
critters.summary: A weasel that often turns white in winter.
critters.fact: Ermine coats can shift seasonally, helping camouflage in snowy conditions.
critters.activeFact: They cache surplus prey, storing food for lean times when hunting is harder.
factHistory: Ermine coats can shift seasonally, helping camouflage in snowy conditions.
They cache surplus prey, storing food for lean times when hunting is harder.

critters.name: American Marten
critters.summary: Forest-dwelling weasel relative that prefers mature woods.
critters.fact: Martens are agile climbers and hunt in trees and on the ground for small animals.
critters.activeFact: They often use hollow logs and tree cavities for shelter during harsh weather.
factHistory: Martens are agile climbers and hunt in trees and on the ground for small animals.
They often use hollow logs and tree cavities for shelter during harsh weather.

critters.name: American Badger
critters.summary: Powerful digger that hunts burrowing prey.
critters.fact: Badgers can excavate quickly, using strong forelimbs and long claws like natural shovels.
critters.activeFact: They often target ground squirrels and rodents, expanding burrows into broad tunnel systems.
factHistory: Badgers can excavate quickly, using strong forelimbs and long claws like natural shovels.
They often target ground squirrels and rodents, expanding burrows into broad tunnel systems.

critters.name: Bald Eagle
critters.summary: Large raptor often seen near open water.
critters.fact: Bald eagles build massive nests that can be reused and expanded year after year.
critters.activeFact: They often scavenge as well as hunt, taking advantage of easy meals when available.
factHistory: Bald eagles build massive nests that can be reused and expanded year after year.
They often scavenge as well as hunt, taking advantage of easy meals when available.

critters.name: Osprey
critters.summary: Fish-hunting raptor that patrols lakes and rivers.
critters.fact: Ospreys dive feet-first to grab fish, using reversible outer toes for a stronger grip.
critters.activeFact: They often hover briefly before plunging, lining up the strike with precise aim.
factHistory: Ospreys dive feet-first to grab fish, using reversible outer toes for a stronger grip.
They often hover briefly before plunging, lining up the strike with precise aim.

critters.name: American Robin
critters.summary: Common yard bird often seen on lawns.
critters.fact: Robins cock their heads to listen for worms and movement in soil before pulling prey out.
critters.activeFact: They can raise multiple broods in a season when conditions are good.
factHistory: Robins cock their heads to listen for worms and movement in soil before pulling prey out.
They can raise multiple broods in a season when conditions are good.

critters.name: Song Sparrow
critters.summary: Small singer common in brushy edges.
critters.fact: Song sparrows have varied local ‚Äòdialects,‚Äô and individuals can learn different song versions.
critters.activeFact: They often stay low in shrubs, hopping through cover and popping up to sing.
factHistory: Song sparrows have varied local ‚Äòdialects,‚Äô and individuals can learn different song versions.
They often stay low in shrubs, hopping through cover and popping up to sing.

critters.name: White-throated Sparrow
critters.summary: Forest-edge sparrow known for clear whistled songs.
critters.fact: Their song is often remembered as ‚ÄòOh-sweet-Canada-Canada‚Äô in rhythm and cadence.
critters.activeFact: They scratch leaf litter with both feet to uncover seeds and insects.
factHistory: Their song is often remembered as ‚ÄòOh-sweet-Canada-Canada‚Äô in rhythm and cadence.
They scratch leaf litter with both feet to uncover seeds and insects.

critters.name: Brown Thrasher
critters.summary: Rusty-brown singer that forages in leaf litter.
critters.fact: Brown thrashers can mimic other birds and chain many different phrases into long songs.
critters.activeFact: They forage by sweeping leaves aside, searching for insects and seeds underneath.
factHistory: Brown thrashers can mimic other birds and chain many different phrases into long songs.
They forage by sweeping leaves aside, searching for insects and seeds underneath.

critters.name: Eastern Bluebird
critters.summary: Blue songbird that uses nest boxes and cavities.
critters.fact: Bluebirds hunt by watching from a perch, then dropping to the ground for insects.
critters.activeFact: They readily use nest boxes, which can boost local breeding success in open areas.
factHistory: Bluebirds hunt by watching from a perch, then dropping to the ground for insects.
They readily use nest boxes, which can boost local breeding success in open areas.

critters.name: Brook Trout
critters.summary: Cold-water trout with bright spotting found in clear streams.
critters.fact: Brook trout thrive in clean, cold streams and are sensitive to warming or low-oxygen water.
critters.activeFact: They often hold behind rocks and logs where current brings food with less effort.
factHistory: Brook trout thrive in clean, cold streams and are sensitive to warming or low-oxygen water.
They often hold behind rocks and logs where current brings food with less effort.

critters.name: Brown Trout
critters.summary: Stream trout known for wariness and strong fights.
critters.fact: Brown trout often feed most actively in low light, using cover during bright daytime hours.
critters.activeFact: They favor undercut banks and deep pools where they can ambush drifting prey.
factHistory: Brown trout often feed most actively in low light, using cover during bright daytime hours.
They favor undercut banks and deep pools where they can ambush drifting prey.

critters.name: Rainbow Trout
critters.summary: Trout species known for acrobatic jumps when hooked or startled.
critters.fact: Rainbow trout often rise to insects on the surface, especially during hatches.
critters.activeFact: They use current seams to feed efficiently where fast and slow water meet.
factHistory: Rainbow trout often rise to insects on the surface, especially during hatches.
They use current seams to feed efficiently where fast and slow water meet.

critters.name: American Toad
critters.summary: Common toad found in yards and woodland edges.
critters.fact: American toads have glands that can secrete toxins as a defense against predators.
critters.activeFact: They often hunt at night, sitting still until insects wander within tongue range.
factHistory: American toads have glands that can secrete toxins as a defense against predators.
They often hunt at night, sitting still until insects wander within tongue range.

critters.name: Spotted Salamander
critters.summary: Secretive woodland amphibian that breeds in vernal pools.
critters.fact: Spotted salamanders spend much of life underground, emerging on rainy nights to migrate to breeding pools.
critters.activeFact: Their eggs are often laid in jelly-like clusters attached to sticks or underwater plants.
factHistory: Spotted salamanders spend much of life underground, emerging on rainy nights to migrate to breeding pools.
Their eggs are often laid in jelly-like clusters attached to sticks or underwater plants.

critters.name: Painted Lady Butterfly
critters.summary: Widespread butterfly often seen in open fields and gardens.
critters.fact: Painted ladies are strong fliers and can migrate long distances depending on seasonal conditions.
critters.activeFact: They nectar on many flowers, making them frequent visitors in sunny open spaces.
factHistory: Painted ladies are strong fliers and can migrate long distances depending on seasonal conditions.
They nectar on many flowers, making them frequent visitors in sunny open spaces.

critters.name: Lady Beetle
critters.summary: Beneficial beetle that eats garden pests.
critters.fact: Lady beetles can consume large numbers of aphids, helping protect plants naturally.
critters.activeFact: They sometimes overwinter in groups, hiding in sheltered cracks and crevices.
factHistory: Lady beetles can consume large numbers of aphids, helping protect plants naturally.
They sometimes overwinter in groups, hiding in sheltered cracks and crevices.

critters.name: Praying Mantis
critters.summary: Ambush predator insect with grasping forelegs.
critters.fact: Praying mantises hold still and strike fast, grabbing prey with spined forelegs.
critters.activeFact: They can rotate their heads to track movement, giving them excellent hunting awareness.
factHistory: Praying mantises hold still and strike fast, grabbing prey with spined forelegs.
They can rotate their heads to track movement, giving them excellent hunting awareness.
